awd_titl_txt: TC: Small: A Foundational and Practical Platform for Host Security Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops the ability to securely monitor host activities, which is the foundation of any host-based security application such as anti-virus software, firewalls, host-based intrusion detection systems, control flow analysis, taint tracking, and more. 
 
The central idea is to use a hybrid approach that combines virtual machine introspection with secure in-VM monitoring to provide the necessary security, efficiency, and flexibility to be useful for a broad range of security applications. The main research activities address the foundational problems inherent to this hybrid architecture, and any other virtualization-based security architecture. Specifically, the project develops: (1) attestation and memory and data structure protection techniques to ensure the security of the trusted computing base (TCB) throughout the lifecycle of the system, (2) algorithms to locate security-critical data structures, reverse-engineer data structure semantics, and automatically generate semantic probes, and (3) algorithms and APIs for developers to divide a security application into in-VM and out-of-VM components. 
 
This project also develops several security monitoring tools based on the hybrid approach, in particular, a system for user input monitoring that securely receives keyboard and mouse events and then determines what application will receive the events and how they will be processed.  This tool is useful for classifying system activity as user-intended or automated.  The automated activity can then be analyzed to identify potentially malicious host events (e.g., bot-generated traffic).

por.por_cntn:
The foundation of any host-based security application is the ability to securely monitor host activities. Unfortunately, practical secure monitoring remains an unfulfilled goal. As a result, applications including anti-virus software, firewalls, host-based intrusion detection systems, control flow analysis, taint tracking, and more all remain vulnerable to malicious tampering or disabling on production systems today. Until this foundational capability can be deployed securely, the current situation will prevail.

This project has developed a hybrid approach that combines virtual machine introspection with secure in-VM monitoring to provide the necessary security, efficiency, and flexibility to be useful for a broad range of security applications. This architecture presents challenges for a practical, secure deployment. Thus, this project has addressed three foundational problems inherent to this hybrid architecture, and any other virtualization-based security architecture: (1) ensuring the security of the trusted computing base (TCB) throughout the lifecycle of the system, (2) obtaining the semantic understanding necessary for building practical and useful monitoring applications, and (3) simplifying deployment of security applications into a non-traditional environment.

This project has developed several security monitoring tools based on our hybrid approach as a means of validation and for making our research results widely available and useful. In particular, this project has developed a system for user input monitoring that securely receives keyboard and mouse events and then determines what application will receive the events and how they will be processed. This tool is useful for classifying system activity as user-intended or automated. The automated activity can then be analyzed to identify potentially malicious host events (e.g., bot-generated traffic).

The ability to securely monitor host activities is a fundamental requirement for computer and network security. This project has delivered a monitoring architecture that is foundational in that it provides robust security protection of the monitoring system using TCB and virtualization technologies. This project enables the development of practical monitoring systems with new techniques to obtain application semantic information necessary for security analysis, and our approach to help identify modules of the monitor to be deployed securely in- VM or out-of-VM to get the full benefits of security, effectiveness, and efficiency that our hybrid architecture provides. This project makes contributions to not only security but also systems, e.g., in performance monitoring and optimization.

The research results of this project have been published in the top-tier security conferences, and tools developed by this project have been adopted by the security industry. In addition, two Ph.D. students completed their theses based on work in this project.

Some of the tools and results from this project have been incorporated into the curriculum development efforts at Georgia Tech. In particular, a new malware analysis system is being developed, which will become an experiment platform for students in several security courses, both undergraduate and graduate, on-campus and on-line.

In recognizing the importance of security importance, a supplement of this project was awarded to explore ways to improve the core undergraduate computer science curriculum so that all computer science graduates will learn the fundamentals of information security. A Security Education Workshop was held in 2013, 2014, and 2015 where educators and representatives from the government and industry exchanged ideas on improving the computer science curriculum with security contents.
